{{EngvarB|date=August 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Dahyan air strike | partof = [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen]] | location = [[Dahyan]], [[Sa'dah governorate]], Yemen | target = Civilian bus | coordinates = {{Coord|17|03|54|N|43|36|01|E|display=inline,title}} | date = | time = | timezone = | type = | fatalities = At least 51 people {{Small|(per Houthi's Health Ministry)}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.efe.com/efe/english/world/death-toll-of-airstrike-on-yemeni-children-s-bus-rises-to-51-79-wounded/50000262-3716934|title=Death toll of airstrike on Yemeni children's bus rises to 51, 79 wounded|work=www.efe.com|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/ICRC_ye/status/1027899330940858368|title=ICRC Yemen on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}} | injuries = At least 48 {{Small|(per the Red Cross){{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/yemen-airstrike-saada-1.4778798|title=Schoolchildren riding bus among dozens killed in Saudi airstrike in Yemen {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-US}}}}
At least 79 people {{Small|(per Houthi's Health Ministry)}} | victims = | perpetrators = [[Armed Forces of Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabian Armed Forces]] | assailants = | susperps = | weapons = | numparts = | dfens = | motive = | website = | module = }} {{Campaignbox Yemeni Crisis}} On 9 August 2018, Saudi Arabian expeditionary aircraft bombed a civilian school bus passing through a crowded market with U.S made bombs in [[Dahyan]], [[Saada Governorate]], [[Yemen]], near the border with [[Saudi Arabia]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/08/yemen-dozens-children-killed-wounded-school-bus-attack-180809085843444.html|title=Yemen: Dozens of civilians killed in school bus attack|date=10 August 2018|website=Al Jazeera|access-date=10 August 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-45128367|title=Strike on Yemen bus kills 29 children|date=9 August 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=10 August 2018|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/airstrike-by-us-ally-on-bus-carrying-yemeni-children-kills-and-wounds-scores/2018/08/09/c047e55e-bbc6-42ff-a5db-4bd2e629f0b6_story.html|title=Airstrike by U.S.-backed Saudi coalition on bus kills dozens of Yemeni children|last=Al-Mujahed|first=Ali|last2=Raghavan|first2=Sudarsan|date=9 August 2018|website=The Washington Post|language=en|access-date=10 August 2018}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/aug/19/us-supplied-bomb-that-killed-40-children-school-bus-yemen|title=US supplied bomb that killed 40 children on Yemen school bus|last=Borger|first=Julian|date=2018-08-19|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-09-17}} At least 40[https://edition.cnn.com/2018/08/17/middleeast/us-saudi-yemen-bus-strike-intl/index.html Bomb that killed 40 children in Yemen was supplied by the US], August 17, 2018, CNN children were killed, all under 15 years old{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/aug/09/dozens-dead-in-yemen-as-bus-carrying-children-hit-by-airstrike-icrc|title=Dozens dead in Yemen as bus carrying children hit by airstrike|last=Dehghan|first=Saeed Kamali|date=9 August 2018|website=The Guardian|language=en|access-date=10 August 2018}} and most under age 10. Sources disagree on the exact number of deaths, but they estimate that the air strike killed about 51 people.{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/children-dead-attack-yemen-market/story?id=57121579|title=Saudi-led coalition airstrike kills dozens of children on bus in Yemen|last=Marsri|first=Lena|date=9 August 2018|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=10 August 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://news.sky.com/story/airstrike-on-childrens-bus-is-a-low-point-in-yemen-war-unicef-11468505|title=Airstrike on children's bus is 'a low point' in Yemen war – UNICEF|work=Sky News|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-GB}} == Attack == According to [[Save the Children]], at the time of the attack the children were on a bus heading back to school from a picnic when the driver stopped to get refreshment at the market in Dahyan. Most of the children were under age 10, according to the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]]. A Red Cross – supported hospital in [[Sa'dah|Saada]] received the bodies of 29 children under 15 years of age and 48 wounded individuals, 30 of whom were children.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/saudi-arabia-airstrike-yemen-kids-killed-bus-dahyan-market-saada-icrc-says/|title=Saudi coalition airstrike in Yemen kills 50, rebels say|access-date=2018-08-13|language=en}} A total of 40 children were killed in the strike.https://edition.cnn.com/2018/08/17/middleeast/us-saudi-yemen-bus-strike-intl/index.html According to a resident of Dahyan, the warplanes had been hovering over the area for more than an hour before they attacked.{{Cite news|url=https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/dozens-children-killed-and-injured-airstrike-yemen-bus-red-cross-says-61507076|title=At least 29 children killed by Saudi-led air strike on Yemeni school bus|work=Middle East Eye|access-date=2018-08-13|language=en}} Another witness said, "Our shops were open and shoppers were walking around as usual. All those who died were residents, children and shop owners."{{Cite news|url=https://ewn.co.za/2018/08/10/saudi-air-strikes-in-yemen-described-as-grotesque|title=Saudi air strikes in Yemen described as 'grotesque'|last=Reuters|access-date=2018-08-13|language=en}} According to Yahya Hussein, a teacher who was traveling separately from the bus, "The scene can't be described—there was body parts and blood everywhere."{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/08/13/middleeast/yemen-children-school-bus-strike-intl/index.html|title=The schoolboys in Yemen were chatting and laughing. Then came the airstrike |first1=Nima |last1=Elbagir |first2=Salma |last2=Abdelaziz |first3=Sheena |last3=McKenzie |first4=Waffa |last4=Munayyer|work=CNN|date=2018-08-13|access-date=2018-08-14}} The bomb that killed the children was a [[MK 82 bomb]] made by [[Lockheed Martin]]. It had been supplied by the [[United States]] to [[Saudi Arabia]]. == Media coverage == The attack came to light after videos were posted on [[Twitter]] depicting the remains of the bus and the children. Images of the victims were aired on the [[Almasirah|Al Masirah TV]] network, highlighting dramatic images of blood and debris-covered children lying on hospital stretchers. The Saudi Arabian coalition later issued a statement saying that they conducted an airstrike in Saada but were targeting [[Houthi]] missile launchers. The mass funeral of the children was aired on the Al Mariah TV network, with thousands of Yemenis participating.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2018/08/14/protests-at-funeral-for-yemeni-children-killed-in-coalition-strike.html|title=Protests at funeral for Yemeni children killed in coalition strike|last=Post|first=The Jakarta|work=The Jakarta Post|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en}} == Reactions == === Domestic === The official Saudi Arabian press agency called the strike a "legitimate military action" which targeted those who were responsible for a rebel missile attack on the Saudi Arabian city of [[Jizan]] on Wednesday.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/09/world/middleeast/yemen-airstrike-school-bus-children.html|title=Saudi Coalition Bombs School Bus in Yemen, Killing Dozens|access-date=10 August 2018|language=en}} They also claimed that the airstrikes "conformed to international and humanitarian laws" and that [[Houthis]] were using children as human shields. Yemeni journalist Nasser Arrabyee reported that there were no Houthis in the vicinity of the strike. A Houthi spokesman said that the coalition showed "clear disregard for civilian life", as the attack had targeted a crowded public place in the city. During the mass funeral of the children, many signs were visible protesting against the United States, Saudi Arabia, and Israel. On 1 September 2018, the Saudi Arabian-led coalition admitted mistakes, expressing regrets and pledged to hold those responsible for the strikes accountable.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-45382561|title='Mistakes' admitted in Yemen bus attack|date=2018-09-01|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-09-02|language=en-GB}} === International === United Nations Secretary-General [[António Guterres]] condemned the attack and called for an independent and prompt investigation, and UNICEF strongly condemned the attack. *{{Cite web|url=https://www.unicef.org/stories/reported-air-strike-school-bus-saada-northern-yemen|title=Reported air strike on school bus in Sa'ada, northern Yemen|website=www.unicef.org|language=en|access-date=10 August 2018}} *{{Cite news|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/08/1016732|title=UN chief condemns air strike that hit school bus in northern Yemen, killing scores of children|date=9 August 2018|work=UN News|access-date=9 August 2018|language=en}} The United States Department of State called for Saudi Arabia to conduct an investigation into the strike.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-usa/u-s-calls-on-saudi-led-coalition-to-probe-yemen-attack-idUSKBN1KU2DD|title=U.S. calls on Saudi-led coalition to probe Yemen attack|last=Beech|first=Eric|date=10 August 2018|work=Reuters|access-date=9 August 2018|editor-last=Zargham|editor-first=Mohammad|language=en-US}} The United Kingdom's Foreign and Commonwealth Office expressed "deep concern", called for a transparent investigation, and called upon all parties to prevent civilian casualties and to co-operate with the UN to reach a lasting political solution in Yemen. *{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/AlistairBurtUK/status/1027929047161077761|title=Alistair Burt on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-08-11|language=en}} *{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/calls-grow-for-investigation-of-deadly-attack-in-yemen-that-hit-school-bus-1533935919|title=Calls Grow for Investigation of Deadly Attack in Yemen That Hit School Bus|last=Fitch|first=Asa|date=2018-08-10|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-08-11|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} UK Foreign Secretary [[Jeremy Hunt]] defended the [[Saudi Arabia–United Kingdom relations|Saudi–British alliance]] as important in fighting Islamists.{{cite news |title=Foreign Secretary defends UK-Saudi ties after Yemen bus deaths |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/uk-45265871/foreign-secretary-defends-uk-saudi-ties-after-yemen-bus-deaths |work=BBC News |date=22 August 2018}} === Non-governmental organisations === The head of the Yemeni delegation of the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] tweeted, "@ICRC_Yemen-supported hospital has received dozens of dead and wounded. Under international humanitarian law, civilians must be protected during conflict." *{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/09/world/middleeast/yemen-airstrike-school-bus-children.html|title=Saudi Coalition Airstrike Hits School Bus in Yemen, Killing Dozens|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}} *{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/ICRC_ye/status/1027459027540893696|title=ICRC Yemen on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}} *{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/yemen-children-dead-bus-airstrike-saudi-coalition-war-attack-a8484626.html|title=Saudi coalition airstrike hit school bus killing dozens of children in Yemen|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-GB}} == See also == {{Portal|War}} * [[Bombing of Mokha|2015 Bombing of Mokha]] * [[2016 Sana'a funeral airstrike]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Yemeni Civil War (2015)}} [[Category:Airstrikes]] [[Category:Attacks in 2018]] [[Category:August 2018 events in Asia]] [[Category:August 2018 events in Yemen]] [[Category:Mass murder in 2018]] [[Category:Saada Governorate]] [[Category:Military intervention in Yemen]] [[Category:Violence against children]] [[Category:Yemeni Crisis (2011–present)]] [[Category:Lockheed Martin]]

revision.comment: /* Boy in the Box */copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]]; [[Template:Citation_Style_documentation#url|url trimming of identifying info]]
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox person |name=Mary Jane Barker |image=maryjaneparker.jpg |image_size=200px |birth_date={{birth date|1953|2|28}} |birth_place=[[Bellmawr, New Jersey]], [[United States]] |death_date=c. {{death date and age|mf=y|1957|2|28|1953|2|28}} |death_place=Bellmawr, New Jersey |disappeared_date=February 25, 1957 |disappeared_place=Bellmawr, New Jersey, U.S. |death_cause=[[Starvation]] | known_for = Mysterious circumstances of death | father = Frank Barker }} On February 25, 1957, '''Mary Jane Barker''', an American 4-year-old girl from [[Bellmawr, New Jersey]] (southeast of [[Philadelphia]]), United States went missing along with her playmate's dog. After an extensive search throughout the city, dubbed by the press as "the largest search in [[South Jersey]]", her dead body was discovered by her playmate in the closet of a vacant house near her home on March 3. The dog bounded out of the closet, seemingly unharmed.
Despite the initial suspicion of foul play, the death was ruled an accident; a case of [[starvation]] and exposure as Barker was unable to escape the closet. Investigators concluded that Barker died on February 28, three days after her disappearance. As a result, the mayor ordered closet doors to open more easily. The press surrounding the Barker case also led to the first calls about the [[Boy in the Box (Philadelphia)|Boy in the Box]].
==Birth and siblings== Mary Jane Barker was born in Bellmawr, New Jersey, U.S., on February 28, 1953, to Mr. and Mrs. Frank Barker. She had two older siblings: Carol Ann, 8 years older; and Frank Jr., 6 years older.<ref name=":1">{{cite news|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1957/03/04/page/1/article/missing-girl-4-found-dead|work=[[Chicago Daily Tribune]]|title=Missing Girl, 4, Found Dead|date=March 4, 1957|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423215256/http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1957/03/04/page/1/article/missing-girl-4-found-dead|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Disappearance== Barker disappeared along with a four-month old black [[spaniel]] puppy at 10:30 a.m. on Monday, February 25, 1957, in Bellmawr.<ref name=":0"/> She was last seen playing in a nearby yard, going to meet with her friend and neighbor, 6-year-old Maria Freitta, the owner of the dog. Police were notified by 1:30 p.m. She was presumed kidnapped, and the next day footprints were found along a nearby stream bank which seemed those of a man, child, and dog. The police stated that the small footprints on the mud matched the size of Barker's shoes.<ref name="timeline">{{cite news|title=Steps In Hunt For Mary Jane|date=March 4, 1957|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer|page=11}}</ref><ref name=iowan/>
===Search=== Her disappearance "touched off an intensive search for a kidnapper or murderer" according to ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]''. It was called "the largest search in [[South Jersey]]."<ref name=inqmjp/> Hundreds of volunteers and police searched the city.<ref name=iowan>{{cite news|title=Girl Missing May Be Case Of Kidnapping|url=http://dailyiowan.lib.uiowa.edu/DI/1957/di1957-02-28.pdf|work=[[The Daily Iowan]]|date=February 28, 1957|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426202122/http://dailyiowan.lib.uiowa.edu/DI/1957/di1957-02-28.pdf|archivedate=April 26, 2016|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> On the first night more than 200 civilians did a foot-by-foot search. Eventually well over a thousand people were involved. Her fourth birthday came and went with no sign of her.<ref name=inqmjp>{{cite news|url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2023/Philadelphia%20PA%20Inquirer/Philadelphia%20PA%20Inquirer%201957/Philadelphia%20PA%20Inquirer%201957%20-%203679.pdf|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=March 4, 1957|title=Missing Girl Found Dead In Closet Of Vacant House Near Her Home|pages=1; 11}}</ref>
On Wednesday, February 27, the parents made an appeal on television to anyone who may have kidnapped Barker, asking them to "leave the child in the nearest church." Vern Lovering, a 43-year old floor sander and convicted child molester had been questioned, and said he was near the Barker home. On Thursday, February 28, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) conducted its own search, and the next day again questioned Lovering after police received a phone call demanding $500 ransom. Police made an appeal to the kidnapper not to "act in haste or do harm to the child."<ref name=timeline/>
The grief of the Barker family was especially acute on February 28 and March 1 since those were the birthdays of Barker and her father, and they were planning to have a joint celebration that week. The police stated that they were working on several leads but had no developments.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mother Certain Mary Jane Barker Has Been Kidnapped|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19570227&id=AW0mAAAAIBAJ&pg=6326,2154855|work=[[The Gettysburg Times]]|date=March 1, 1957|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423220151/https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19570227&id=AW0mAAAAIBAJ&pg=6326,2154855|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> On Saturday, March 2, the FBI was officially called in following the provisions of the [[Federal Kidnapping Act]]. Several nearby dumps were searched to no avail.<ref name=timeline/>
==Discovery of body== On Sunday, March 3, Maria Freitta, the owner of the dog and the playmate of Barker, went with her mother to a vacant, newly built [[ranch house]] next door to her home. It was on 433 2nd Ave, owned by her aunt and uncle, Mr. and Mrs. Pat Vecchia.<ref name=":1"/> Maria managed to open a 3 ft × 5 ft bedroom closet's door, and her missing dog bounded out of the closet and leaped happily at her.<ref name=":1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2691586/the_times/|work=[[The Times of Northwest Indiana|The Times]]|date=March 4, 1957|page=1|accessdate=June 26, 2015|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|title=Girl Dies, Puppy Lives|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423220400/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2691586/the_times/|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}} {{Open access}}</ref> Also in the closet was Barker, dead, in a seated position, the hood of her blue coat partially covering her blonde hair.<ref name=inqmjp/> She was found in the same clothes she had on when she disappeared.<ref name=":1"/> Bits of fur from her hat were rubbed off.<ref name=inqmjp/> Police Chief Edward Garrity stated he believed that Barker had recently been placed in the closet as the puppy had been fed recently, and there was no animal waste in the closet despite the dog not being housebroken.<ref name=eagle/>
During previous searches, including a visit by a repairman,<ref name=eagle>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19570304&id=QuQiAAAAIBAJ&pg=5434,1508482|title=Jersey Girl|date=March 4, 1957|work=[[Reading Eagle]]|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423220508/https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19570304&id=QuQiAAAAIBAJ&pg=5434,1508482|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> no dog was heard.<ref name=":2">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2691658/the_times_standard/|work=[[Times-Standard]]|title=Missing Youngster Found Starved To Death In Closet of New Home|date=March 4, 1957|page=21|accessdate=June 26, 2015|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423220909/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2691658/the_times_standard/|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}} {{Open access}}</ref> The house had been searched three times before, but the bedroom closet where her body was found was not searched.<ref name=":0"/> Rev. Harry McIntyre looked in bedroom closets on February 26,<ref name=inqmjp/> but it never occurred to him to search the front-bedroom closet.<ref name=starved>{{cite news|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1957/03/05/page/5/article/rules-girl-4-starved-in-closet|title=Rules Girl, 4, Starved In Closet|date=March 5, 1957|work=[[The Chicago Tribune]]|archiveurl=https://archive.is/b6lmg/image|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> "I concentrated on the basement, believing the girl might have fallen down the stairs," he said.<ref name=inqmjp/> A volunteer fireman, John Reeves, also searched the first-floor bedroom but not the closet.<ref name=starved/> Barker may have been too frightened to cry out.<ref name=":4">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2693365/the_daily_times/|work=The Daily Times|title=Pet Dog Is Liquidated To Probe Little Girl's Death|date=March 5, 1957|page=1|accessdate=June 26, 2015|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423221909/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2693365/the_daily_times/|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}} {{Open access}}</ref>
[[File:MaryJaneBarkerdoor.png|thumb|160px|The lock on the closet door.]] Although the door was unlocked, a thumb screw inside apparently made it difficult for a child to open.<ref name=":0"/><ref name=":2"/> The door had a knob on the outside, but only a small turn latch on the inside.<ref name=starved/>
==Autopsy== On March 4, the autopsy indicated Barker had nothing in her system since some [[chocolate milk]] the morning of her disappearance,<ref name=inqmjp/><ref name=starv/> and had not eaten since she vanished. There was no indication of foul play;<ref name=amste>{{cite news|url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper4/Amsterdam%20NY%20Daily%20Democrat%20and%20Recorder/Amsterdam%20NY%20Daily%20Democrat%20and%20Recorder%201957%20Mar-Apr%20Grayscale/Amsterdam%20NY%20Daily%20Democrat%20and%20Recorder%201957%20Mar-Apr%20Grayscale%20-%200026.pdf|work=Amsterdam Evening Recorder|title=Closet Yields Body of Child, Missing 5 Days|date=March 4, 1957|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423222226/http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper4/Amsterdam%20NY%20Daily%20Democrat%20and%20Recorder/Amsterdam%20NY%20Daily%20Democrat%20and%20Recorder%201957%20Mar-Apr%20Grayscale/Amsterdam%20NY%20Daily%20Democrat%20and%20Recorder%201957%20Mar-Apr%20Grayscale%20-%200026.pdf|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> no signs of violence or [[Sexual abuse|sexual molestation]].<ref name=inqmjp/> It was found she must have lived in the closet for three days without food or drink. An inspection of the closet showed marks from her attempt to escape.<ref name=":0"/>
It was found the dog was with her the whole time.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2693404/altoona_tribune/|accessdate=June 26, 2015|page=1|date=March 5, 1957|work=[[Altoona Tribune]]|title=No Foul Play Found In Death of Mary Jane Barker|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423222511/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2693404/altoona_tribune/|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}} {{Open access}}</ref> The dog was "alive and frisky", which initially led investigators to believe she had been in the closet only a short time.<ref name=eagle/> The dog was first taken to a local veterinarians for study, but they concluded that it was possible that the dog had to be put down to examine his stomach contents.<ref name=inqmjp/> Dr. Robert Sauer, the veterinarian, stated that the survival of the dog for several days was consistent with the stamina of such an animal.<ref name="starved" /> On March 4, the dog was euthanized in order to allow veterinarians from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] to examine its stomach contents, and establish why the dog outlived Barker.<ref name=":0" /> Investigators wanted to know if the dog was without food or water since Barker's disappearance.<ref name=":4" />
[[Camden County, New Jersey|Camden County]] Coroner Robert J. Blake ruled her death an accident; a case of starvation with exposure as a contributing factor.<ref name=":0">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2691572/the_newsherald/|work=[[The News-Herald (Ohio)|The News-Herald]]|page=12|date=March 5, 1957|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate=June 26, 2015|title=Rule Girl Died of Starvation and Exposure in Closet|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423215420/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2691572/the_newsherald/|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}} {{Open access}}</ref><ref name=starved/><ref name=starv>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19570305&id=BW0mAAAAIBAJ&pg=6234,1865085|work=[[The Gettysburg Times]]|title=Mary Jane Barker Died of "Starvation and Exposure"|date=March 5, 1957|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423222126/https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19570305&id=BW0mAAAAIBAJ&pg=6234,1865085|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> A spokesman for the coroner said Barker became trapped in the closet, and [[Voodoo death|died of fright]] and starvation.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://newspapers.library.in.gov/cgi-bin/indiana?a=d&d=TDB19570304-01.1.1|title=Girl, 4, Died of Starvation|date=March 4, 1957|work=The Daily Banner|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170424040039/https://newspapers.library.in.gov/cgi-bin/indiana?a=d&d=TDB19570304-01.1.1|archivedate=April 24, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Due to a hole in the closet, she could not have [[Asphyxia|suffocated]].<ref name="inqmjp" />
==Aftermath== On March 7, Mayor Cornelius Devennel ordered all closet doors to be equipped with special knobs that can open easily from both inside and outside. This order was made mandatory for all new home constructions or reconstructions. A ceremony in her memory was held at the St. Francis de Sales Church that same day.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19570308&id=CG0mAAAAIBAJ&pg=2036,1616954|title=Pay Last Respects To Mary Jane Barker|work=[[The Gettysburg Times]]|date=March 8, 1957|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170423222615/https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19570308&id=CG0mAAAAIBAJ&pg=2036,1616954|archivedate=April 23, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> On March 20, radio station [[WPEN (FM)|WPEN]] presented Freitta with a new puppy, an [[English Setter]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Gift to Child: Destroyed Pet Dog Replaced|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/22501975/|work=[[Corpus Christi Caller-Times]]|date=April 20, 1957|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170424035257/https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/22501975/|archivedate=April 24, 2017|deadurl=no|page=4}}</ref>
===Boy in the Box=== The press surrounding the Barker case led to the first calls about the [[Boy in the Box (Philadelphia)|Boy in the Box]]. Frank Guthrum, who discovered the boy, had decided not to call the police until he listened to reports of the Barker case on his car radio.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZUDh6fV8DKUC&pg=PT30&q=%2522mary%2520jane%2520barker%2522%2520bellmawr|title=The Murder Room: The Heirs of Sherlock Holmes Gather to Solve the World's Most Perplexing Cold Cases|last=Capuzzo|first=Michael|date=2010|publisher=[[Penguin Books]]|isbn=9781101458952}}</ref><ref name="box">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nAbmBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA62|title=Boy in the Box: The Unsolved Case of America's Unknown Child|date=2008|publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]]|isbn=0762798688|page=62|last1=Stout|first1=David}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Death|New Jersey}} * [[List of solved missing persons cases]] * [[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]] *[[List of unusual deaths]] {{clear}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{findagrave|169997080|Mary Jane Barker}}

{{Infobox writer | embed = | honorific_prefix = | name = Dorothea Mackellar | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=AUS|size=100%|OBE}} | image = Dorothea Mackellar.jpg | image_size = 200 | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = {{no wrap|Isobel Marion Dorothea Mackellar}} | birth_date = {{Birth date|1885|07|01|df=y}} | birth_place = ''[[Dunara]]'', {{NSWcity|Point Piper}}, [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]], Australia | death_date = {{Death date and age|1968|01|14|1885|07|01|df=y}} | death_place = {{NSWcity|Paddington}}, Sydney, New South Wales | resting_place = [[Waverley Cemetery]] | occupation = [[Poet]] | language = | residence = | nationality = Australian | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genres = {{bulleted list|[[Bush poet|Bush poetry]]|Novels}}<!-- or: | genres = --> | subject = <!-- or: | subjects = --> | movement = | notableworks = ''[[My Country]]''<!-- or: | notablework = --> | spouse = <!-- or: | spouses = --> | partner = <!-- or: | partners = --> | children = | relatives = Sir [[Charles Mackellar]] {{small|(father)}} | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = 1908{{spaced endash}}1926 | module = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.org}} --> | portaldisp = <!-- "on", "yes", "true", etc; or omit --> }} [[Image:(1)Dunara.jpg|thumb|''Dunara'', Mackellar's childhood home in [[Point Piper, New South Wales|Point Piper]]]] '''Isobel Marion Dorothea Mackellar''' (better known as Dorothea Mackellar), {{post-nominals|country=AUS|OBE}} (1 July 1885 – 14 January 1968) was an [[List of Australian poets|Australian]] [[poet]] and fiction writer.<ref name="adb">{{cite web|author=Kingston, Beverley|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/mackellar-isobel-marion-dorothea-7383|title=Mackellar, Isobel Marion Dorothea (1885–1968)|accessdate=2 August 2012|work=[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]], Volume 10|publisher=[[Melbourne University Press|MUP]]|year=1986}}</ref> Her poem ''[[My Country]]'' is widely known in Australia, especially its second stanza, which begins: "''I love a sunburnt country/A land of sweeping plains,/Of ragged mountain ranges,/Of droughts and flooding rains."''<ref>[http://www.womenaustralia.info/leaders/biogs/WLE0510b.htm MacKellar, Isobel Marion Dorothea (Dorothea) (1885 - 1968)], ''The Encyclopedia of Women and Leadership in Twentieth-Century Australia''</ref>
==Life== [[File:Mackellar as a "Grace" (1918).jpg|thumb|left|Dorothea Mackellar dressed as one of the Graces for [[Ethel Knight Kelly|Mrs. T.H. Kelly's]] Italian Red Cross Day tableaux at the Palace Theatre, 20 June 1918]] The third child and only daughter of physician and parliamentarian Sir [[Charles Mackellar]] and his wife Marion MacKellar (née Buckland), the daughter of Thomas Buckland, she was born in the family home ''[[Dunara]]'' at [[Point Piper]], [[Sydney]], Australia in 1885. Her later home was ''Cintra'' at [[Darling Point, New South Wales|Darling Point]] (built in 1882 by [[Lindesay, Darling Point#The Macintosh family in residence|John Mackintosh]] for his son James), and in 1925, she commissioned a summer cottage (in reality a substantial home with colonnaded verandah overlooking Pittwater), "Tarrangaua" at [[Lovett Bay, New South Wales|Lovett Bay]], an isolated location on [[Pittwater]] reachable only by boat (this home is currently the residence of the novelist and author [[Susan Duncan]] and her husband, Bob Story, and features prominently in a number of Susan's books). A woman of independent means, she published poetry and other works between 1908 and 1926 and was active in the Sydney literary scene of the 1930s, being involved with the Sydney Publishers, Editors and Novelists Club, the Bush Book Club of New South Wales and the Sydney P.E.N. Club. In her later years she ceased writing and, suffering poor health, her last eleven years were spent in a nursing home in [[Randwick, New South Wales|Randwick]] where she died in 1968, aged 82. She is buried in [[Waverley Cemetery]], in Sydney's Eastern suburbs in Australia.<ref>[http://www.wikitree.com/wiki/Mackellar-13 WikiTree: Isobel Marion Dorothea Mackellar]</ref>
==Literary works== Although she was raised in a professional urban family, Mackellar's poetry is usually regarded as quintessential [[bush poet]]ry, inspired by her experience on her brothers' farms near [[Gunnedah, New South Wales|Gunnedah]], in the north-west of [[New South Wales]]. Her best-known poem is ''[[My Country]]'', written at age 19<ref name="adb"/> while homesick in [[England]], and first published in the [[London]] [[The Spectator|''Spectator'']] in 1908 under the title ''Core of My Heart'': the second stanza of this poem is among the best known in [[Australia]]. Four volumes of her collected verse were published: ''The Closed Door'' (published in 1911, contained the first appearance of ''My Country''); ''The Witch Maid, and Other Verses'' (1914); ''Dreamharbour'' (1923); and ''Fancy Dress'' (1926).
In addition to writing poems, Mackellar also wrote novels, one by herself, ''Outlaw's Luck'' (1913), and at least two in collaboration with [[Ruth Bedford]]. These are ''The Little Blue Devil'' (1912) and ''Two's Company'' (1914). According to Dale Spender, little has been written or is yet known about the circumstances behind this collaboration.<ref>Spender, Dale (1988) ''Writing a New World: Two Centuries of Australian Women Writers'', London: Pandora p. 219</ref>
==Honours == In the New Year's Day Honours of 1968, Dorothea Mackellar was appointed an Officer of the [[Order of the British Empire]] for her contribution to [[Australian literature]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1108726&search_type=advanced&showInd=true|title=MACKELLAR, Isobel Marion Dorothea|work=It's an Honour|accessdate=2009-11-26}}</ref> She died two weeks later in [[Paddington, New South Wales]] after a fall. She is buried with her father and family in [[Waverley Cemetery]] overlooking the open ocean. Also her poem ''Colour'', her own favourite, was read at the service.<ref>[http://www.waverley.nsw.gov.au/library/localstudies/historical/cm_wlk_1.htm Waverley Cemetery - A Walk Through History No. 1] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308201339/http://www.waverley.nsw.gov.au/library/localstudies/historical/cm_wlk_1.htm |date=2008-03-08 }}</ref>
==Legacy== A [[Division of Mackellar|federal electorate]] covering half of Sydney's [[Northern Beaches (Sydney)|Northern Beaches]] is named in her honour as well as a street in the [[Canberra]] suburb of [[Cook, Australian Capital Territory|Cook]]. (The Canberra suburb of [[McKellar, Australian Capital Territory|McKellar]] was not named after her, but is often assumed to have been.)
On [[Australia Day]], 26 January 1983, a memorial to Dorothea Mackellar was unveiled and dedicated in ANZAC Park, Gunnedah.<ref>[http://monumentaustralia.org.au/themes/people/arts/display/21461-dorothea-mackellar Monument Australia]. Retrieved 22 February 2014</ref> The centrepiece of the memorial, a statue of Mackellar on horseback by Dennis Adams, was a temporary fibreglass version. The finished bronze version was installed in September 1983.<ref>[http://www.dorothea.com.au/index.php/about-us/sculpture-artwork/ dorothea mackellar poetry awards] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227225156/http://www.dorothea.com.au/index.php/about-us/sculpture-artwork/ |date=February 27, 2014 }}. Retrieved 22 February 2014</ref>
In conjunction with the January unveiling, there was an exhibition of a series of 34 water colour paintings by [[Jean Isherwood]] illustrating the writer's most famous poem, ''My Country''. The watercolours were eventually put on permanent display in the Gunnedah Bicentennial Regional Gallery. Isherwood set about painting a series of oils based on the watercolours which were exhibited at the Artarmon Galleries in Sydney in 1986.
In 1984, Gunnedah resident Mikie Maas created the "Dorothea Mackellar Poetry Awards", which has grown into a nationwide poetry competition for Australian school students.
