revision.text:
{{Infobox non-profit | name = Inspiration Mars Foundation | image = Inspiration Mars Banner Graphic jpeg.jpg | image_size = 295px | caption = "Send Two People, Take Everyone" | mission = 2018 crewed [[Mars flyby|Mars Flyby]], or alternatively a 2021 [[Crewed Venus Flyby|Venus flyby]] followed by a [[Mars flyby]] | founder = [[Dennis Tito]] | type = [[501(c)(3)]] (pending, {{asof|2013|04|lc=y}}) | tax_id = | registration_id = | founded_date = {{Start date|2013|01|25}} | location = Delaware[http://nasawatch.com/archives/2013/04/inspiration-mar-2.html Inspiration Mars Wants To Use ISS], NASAwatch, 15 April 2013 | coordinates = | origins = | key_people = [[Dennis Tito]]
[[Jane Poynter]]
[[Taber MacCallum]]
Joe Rothenberg
[[Miles O'Brien (journalist)|Miles O'Brien]]
Jonathan Clark
Thomas Squire | area_served = [[Earth]]/[[Mars]]/[[Venus]] | products = | services = | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | motto = "Now is the Time" | former name = | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Inspiration Mars Foundation''' is an American [[nonprofit organization]] founded by [[Dennis Tito]] that in 2013 proposed to launch a crewed mission to [[Planetary flyby|flyby]] [[Mars]] in January 2018, or 2021 if they missed the first [[Synodic period|synodic opportunity]] in 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/11/20/dennis-titos-prepared-remarks-congress-human-mars-mission/ |title=Dennis Tito's Prepared Remarks Before Congress on Human Mars Mission at Parabolic Arc |publisher=Parabolicarc.com |date=2013-11-20 |accessdate=2013-12-07}} Their website became defunct by late 2015 but it is archived by the [[Internet Archive]].{{cite web|url=http://inspirationmars.org/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013012955/http://inspirationmars.org/ |archivedate=13 October 2015|title=The Foundation}} The Foundation's future plans are unclear. ==History== On 27 February 2013, the Inspiration Mars Foundation held a press conference in the [[National Press Club (United States)|National Press Club]] to announce their plan to procure space hardware, launch vehicle services, and select a two-person married couple as crew, and then attempt to [[fundraising|raise the funding]] necessary to [[space launch|launch]] a mission to Mars in 2018. Dennis Tito said he was going to fund the foundation with $100 million for the first years of operation. At the 2013 conference, however, Dennis Tito indicated that the plan was impossible without significant investment from NASA and the use of NASA spacecraft.{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn24633-ambitious-mars-joyride-cannot-succeed-without-nasa.html?page=1 |title=Ambitious Mars joy-ride cannot succeed without NASA - space - 21 November 2013 |publisher=[[New Scientist]] |date=2013-11-21 |accessdate=2013-12-07}} NASA, however, was an unwilling partner.{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2013/11/20/dennis_tito_it_will_take_less_than_1_billion_to_make_mars_mission_happen/|title=Dennis Tito: It will take "less than $1 billion" to make Mars mission happen|first=Lindsay|last=Abrams|publisher=}} ===Funding=== The total cost of the mission was projected to be between US$1 and US$2 billion. {{cite news |last=Koebler|first=Jason |title=Expert: Dennis Tito's Mars Flyby Has '1-in-3' Chance of Succeeding |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2013/03/01/expert-dennis-titos-mars-flyby-has-1-in-3-chance-of-succeeding |accessdate=2013-03-07 |newspaper=US News |date=2013-03-01 |quote=''At a news conference in Washington, D.C., Tito said he's tired of waiting for NASA to send humans to Mars, and that he'd help finance the between $1 and $2 billion needed to complete the mission.''}} Tito planned to fund the foundation's cost for the first two years. Then, the foundation planned to raise funds from industry and individuals. However, in testimony before congress in November 2013, Tito indicated that he expected private donors to only provide around $300 million, leaving the need for an additional investment of $700 million from the US government. NASA responded that whilst they were willing to share technical and programmatic expertise with Inspiration Mars, they were unable to commit to sharing expenses with them.{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2013/11/20/dennis_tito_it_will_take_less_than_1_billion_to_make_mars_mission_happen/ |title=Dennis Tito: It will take "less than $1 billion" to make Mars mission happen |publisher=Salon.com |date=2013-11-20 |accessdate=2013-12-07}} The foundation's funding model, dependent on an unwilling partner, was broken. In March 2014, [[SpaceX]] indicated that they had also been contacted by Inspiration Mars, but that accommodating such requirements would require some additional work and that such work was not a part of the current focus of SpaceX. {{cite AV media|people=Gwynne Shotwell |date=2014-03-21 |title=Broadcast 2212: Special Edition, interview with Gwynne Shotwell |medium=audio file |url=http://archived.thespaceshow.com/shows/2212-BWB-2014-03-21.mp3 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322013556/http://archived.thespaceshow.com/shows/2212-BWB-2014-03-21.mp3 |archivedate=22 March 2014 |format=mp3 |time=11:20–12:10 |publisher=The Space Show |id=2212 |quote= |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} ==Proposal== [[File:Inspiration Mars trajectory.svg|thumb|299px|Approximate Inspiration Mars Trajectory (not to scale)]] [[File:Artist's Concept of Inspiration Mars Capsule.jpg|thumb|299px|Artist's Concept of Inspiration Mars Capsule and Hab.]] [[File:Inspiration Mars Periapsis.jpg|thumb|299px|Inspiration Mars Periapsis.]] The proposal, that was never funded, was based on a [[free return trajectory]] to allow the [[spacecraft]] to use the smallest possible amount of [[rocket propellant|propellant]] to flyby Mars and return to Earth. Leaders of the Foundation stated that the January 2018 launch window offered a rare orbit opportunity to travel to Mars and return to Earth in 501 days.{{cite news |last=Morring|first=Frank, Jr. |title=Serious Intent About 2018 Human Mars Mission |url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/AW_03_04_2013_p24-553876.xml |accessdate=2013-03-07 |newspaper=Aviation Week and Space Technology |date=2013-03-04 }} Their backup plan involved a mission that would begin in 2021 but be 88 days longer in duration. They stated it would require both a flyby of Venus and a fly-by of Mars. The flight would take the spacecraft to within 800 kilometres of the surface of Venus, using the planet for a [[gravity assist]] to speed the onward travel to Mars.{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn24633-ambitious-mars-joyride-cannot-succeed-without-nasa.html |title=Ambitious Mars joy-ride cannot succeed without NASA - space - 21 November 2013 |publisher=New Scientist |date=2013-11-21 |accessdate=2013-12-07}} According to a paper written by Dennis Tito,{{CN|date=October 2018}} "the mission would require no maneuvers except small course corrections after a [[Trans-Mars injection|trans-Martian injection]] burn, [and] would allow no aborts. ... [It will] use [[low Earth orbit]] [[launch vehicle|launch]] and [[List of crewed spacecraft|crewed-spacecraft technology]], outfitted for the long duration of a flight to Mars." They speculated that when the spacecraft returned to Earth it would reenter the atmosphere at 50 000 km per hour (ca 13.9 km/s), which was faster than any previous return.{{cite journal|author1=Nigel Henbest|authorlink1=Nigel Henbest|title=Race to Mars: Who will be first to the Red Planet?|journal=New Scientist|date=13 July 2013|pages=42–45|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg21929252.100-race-to-mars-who-will-be-first-to-the-red-planet.html?full=true#.VS-3QKO8-D8}} ===Student design competition=== During the 16th Annual International Mars Society Convention in 2013, the Mars Society announced the launch of an international engineering competition for student teams to propose design concepts for the architecture of the Inspiration Mars mission. The contest was open to university engineering student teams.{{cite web|url=http://www.marssociety.org/home/inspiration-mars/rules |title=Rules |publisher=The Mars Society |date= |accessdate=2013-12-07}} The design contest took place on August 9, 2014, and was won by an international team from [[Purdue University]] in US and [[Keio University]] in Japan.http://www.archives.marssociety.org/home/press/announcements/teamkanauwinsinspirationmarsstudentdesigncontest |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{dead link|date=April 2017}} ==Critiques== A spokesman for NASA stated that "Inspiration Mars's proposed schedule is a significant challenge due to life support systems, space radiation response, habitats and the human psychology of being in a small spacecraft for over 500 days", but that "we remain open to further collaboration as their proposal and plans for a later mission develop".{{cite web|first=Joel|last=Achenbach |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/going-to-mars-billionaire-dennis-tito-plans-manned-mission-with-possible-2017-launch/2013/11/20/b859bc76-51e8-11e3-9fe0-fd2ca728e67c_story.html |title=Going to Mars: Billionaire Dennis Tito plans manned mission with possible 2017 launch |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2011-02-24 |accessdate=2013-12-07}} John Logsdon, professor emeritus at George Washington University's Space Policy Institute, also found the short preparation time-frame wanting, saying that it is "totally implausible" for a mission to be launched in 2018, although the"Plan B" mission might be possible "if the stars align".{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/going-to-mars-billionaire-dennis-tito-plans-manned-mission-with-possible-2017-launch/2013/11/20/b859bc76-51e8-11e3-9fe0-fd2ca728e67c_story_1.html |title=Going to Mars: Billionaire Dennis Tito plans manned mission with possible 2017 launch |publisher=The Washington Post |date=2013-06-20 |accessdate=2013-12-07}} It is unclear whether the Foundation is still in operation as their website is now defunct. ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Colonization of Mars]] * [[Deep Space Industries]] * [[Effect of spaceflight on the human body]] * [[Human mission to Mars]] * [[List of manned Mars mission plans]] * [[Mars Direct]] * [[Mars to Stay]] * [[Private spaceflight]] * ''[[The Case for Mars]]'' {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{cite news |title=The Crazy Plan to Fly Two Humans to Mars in 2018 |first=Michael |last=Belfiore |url=http://www.popularmechanics.com/science/space/moon-mars/the-crazy-plan-to-fly-two-humans-to-mars-in-2018-15152667 |newspaper=[[Popular Mechanics]] |date=27 February 2013 |accessdate=28 February 2013}} {{cite news |title=Tycoon wants to send married couple on Mars flyby |first=Seth |last=Borenstein |url=http://apnews.excite.com/article/20130227/DA4N93K83.html |publisher=Excite |agency=Associated Press |date=27 February 2013 |accessdate=3 March 2013}} {{cite news |title=The First Human Mission to Mars in 2018 (Updated) |first=Marc |last=Boucher |url=http://spaceref.com/mars/the-first-human-mission-to-mars-in-2018.html |work=SpaceRef |date=20 February 2013 |accessdate=28 February 2013}} {{cite news |title=How a millionaire spaceflier intends to send astronauts past Mars in 2018|first=Alan |last=Boyle|url=http://cosmiclog.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/21/17038750-how-a-millionaire-spaceflier-intends-to-send-astronauts-past-mars-in-2018?lite |work=Cosmic Log |publisher=NBCNews.com |date= |accessdate=28 February 2013}} {{cite news |title=Space Tourist to Announce Daring Manned Mars Voyage for 2018 |first=Adam |last=Mann |url=https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2013/02/dennis-tito-mars |work=Wired |date=20 February 2013 |accessdate=28 February 2013}} {{cite news |title=Private Mission to Mars in 2018: Who Should Go? |first=Clara |last=Moskowitz |url=http://www.space.com/19998-inspiration-mars-mission-married-crew.html |work=space.com |date=28 February 2013 |accessdate=2 March 2013}} {{cite news |title=Millionaire space tourist planning ‘historic journey’ to Mars in 2018 |first=Max |last=Sonnenberg |url=http://thespacereporter.com/2013/02/millionaire-space-tourist-planning-historic-journey-to-mars-in-2018/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130226090920/http://thespacereporter.com/2013/02/millionaire-space-tourist-planning-historic-journey-to-mars-in-2018/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=26 February 2013 |newspaper=The Space Reporter |date=23 February 2013 |accessdate=28 February 2013 }} }} == External links == {{Commons category|Inspiration Mars}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20151013012955/http://inspirationmars.org/ Official website, now defunct] * Flickr: [https://www.flickr.com/photos/94053242@N04/ Inspiration Mars] photo stream * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ksbGcXnuHLU Earth/Mars/IM capsule 501-day mission orbital position animation], Inspiration Mars Foundation, February 2013. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130319140952/http://www.inspirationmars.org/Inspiration%20Mars_Feasibility%20Analysis_IEEE.pdf Feasibility Analysis] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aLfvFp3eFj8 Introductory Press Conference, 27 February 2013] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I4oAQ1pOKnI#! Inspiration Mars: 29th National Space Symposium]: panel discussion, Dennis Tito, Taber MacCallum, Jonathan Clark, and Jane Poynter, Colorado Springs, Colorado, 11 April 2013. *[http://www.parabolicarc.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Inspiration_Mars_Vehicle3.jpg Newer concept] {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Human missions to Mars}} {{Venus spacecraft}} {{portal bar|Mars}} [[Category:Human spaceflight]] [[Category:Exploration of Mars]] [[Category:Scientific research foundations in the United States]] [[Category:Dennis Tito]] [[Category:Missions to Mars]] [[Category:Human missions to Mars]] [[Category:Missions to Venus]] [[Category:Colonization of Mars]] [[Category:Proposed space probes]] [[Category:2013 establishments in Delaware]]

{{Infobox company | name = Institute for the Future | logo = IFTF_logo_2b.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | former_name = | type = Not for profit | industry = Future Forecasting | founded = 1968 in [[Middletown, Connecticut]], United States | founders = [[Frank Davidson]], [[Olaf Helmer]], [[Paul Baran]], [[Arnold Kramish]], and Theodore Gordon | hq_location = 201 Hamilton Avenue | hq_location_city = [[Palo Alto]] | hq_location_country = United States | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = Marina Gorbis | products = | brands = | services = Ten Year Forecast, Technology Horizons, Health Horizons | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | ratio = <!-- for BANKS ONLY --> | rating = <!-- for BANKS ONLY --> | website = {{URL|iftf.org}} }} The '''Institute for the Future''' ('''IFTF''') is a [[Palo Alto, California]], US–based not-for-profit [[think tank]]. It was established, in 1968, as a spin-off from the [[RAND Corporation]] to help organizations plan for the long-term future, a subject known as [[futures studies]].<ref name="ref_Cornish">{{cite book |title= Futuring: The Exploration of the Future |author=Edward Cornish |publisher=World Future Society |year=2004 |pages=196–97 |isbn=0930242572 |access-date=19 Feb 2016 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=phGB2Hc3XZ8C&pg=PA196#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
== History ==
=== Genesis === First references to the idea of an ''Institute for the Future'' may be found in a 1966 Prospectus by [[Olaf Helmer]] and others.<ref name="ref_IFTFProspectus">{{cite web |author1=Olaf Helmer|title=Prospectus for an Institute for the Future |url=https://saltworks.stanford.edu/catalog/druid:hn553xs4979 |date=26 May 1966 |publisher=Organising Committee for an Institute for the Future |access-date=19 Feb 2016|display-authors=etal}}</ref> While at [[RAND Corporation]], Helmer had already been involved with developing the [[Delphi method]] of [[futures studies]]. He, and others, wished to extend the work further with an emphasis on examining multiple scenarios. This can be seen in the prospectus summary: *''To explore systematically the possible futures for our [USA] nation and for the international community.'' *''To ascertain which among these possible futures seems desirable, and why.'' *''To seek means by which the probability of their occurrence can be enhanced through appropriate purposeful action.''<ref name="ref_Cornish" />
=== First years === The Institute opened in 1968, in [[Middletown, Connecticut]]. The initial group was led by [[Frank Davidson]] and included [[Olaf Helmer]], [[Paul Baran]], [[Arnold Kramish]], and Theodore Gordon.<ref name="ref_Cornish" /> <!-- NB: 1. [[Theodore Gordon]] article is about a different person 2. George Mandanis was mentioned in earlier version of article, but is not referred to in cites. Add back if that changes. -->
The Institute’s work initially relied on the forecasting methods built upon by Helmer while at RAND. The [[Delphi method]] was used to glean information from multiple anonymous sources. It was augmented by [[Cross Impact Analysis]], which encouraged analysts to consider multiple future scenarios.<ref name="ref_millett">{{cite journal |title=Should Probabilities Be Used with Scenarios? |author=Stephen M. Millett |url=http://archive.cspo.org/projects/plausibility/files/read_Millett-Should-Probabilities-Be-Used-with-Scenerios.pdf |date=May 2009 |publisher=Journal of Future Studies |isbn= |pages=61–68 |quote=''[Helmer] and his close associate, Selwyn Enzer, developed a computer-based cross-impact model to generate multiple scenarios as alternative futures.'' |access-date=24 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303085919/http://archive.cspo.org/projects/plausibility/files/read_Millett-Should-Probabilities-Be-Used-with-Scenerios.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df= }}</ref>
While precise and powerful, the methods that had been developed in a corporate environment were oriented to providing business and economic analyses. At a 1971 conference on [[mathematical modelling]] Helmer noted the need for similar improvements in societal modelling.<ref name="ref_helmersoc">{{cite journal |title= ''The Role of Futures Research in Societal Modelling'' |author=Olaf Helmer |journal=International Seminar on Trends in Mathematical Modelling: Venice, 13–18 December 1971 |editor=Nigel Hawkes |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zVHuCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA9&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjFyYy-rYrLAhUGJpQKHcbKBjUQ6AEIJTAA#v=onepage&f=false |date=May 2009 |publisher=Springer Science and Business Media |isbn= |pages=9–13 |access-date=24 February 2016}}</ref> Early attempts at doing so included a ‘Future State of the Union’ report, formatted according to the traditional US Presidential address to the Nation.<ref name="ref_FSOU">{{citation |title=''On the Future State of the Union'' |author=Olaf Helmer |journal=Report R-27 |url= |date=1972 |publisher=Institute for the Future |isbn= |quote= |access-date=}}</ref>
Despite establishing an excellent reputation for painstaking analysis of future analyses and forecasting methods, various problems meant that the Institute struggled to find its footing at first. In 1970 Helmer took over the leadership from Davidson, and the Institute shifted its Headquarters to [[Menlo Park, California]].<ref name="ref_Rescher">{{cite book |title=Studies in 20th Century Philosophy |author=Nicholas Rescher |page=203 |publisher=Ontos Verlag |date=28 Feb 2005 |isbn=3937202781 |access-date=19 Feb 2016 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zbK3DklrwEkC&pg=PA203#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
In 1971 [[Roy Amara]] took over from Helmer, who continued to run the Middletown office until his departure in 1973.<ref name="ref_Cornish" /><ref name="ref_Rescher"/> Amara held this position until 1990. During Amara's presidency, the Institute conducted some of the earliest studies of the impact of the [[ARPANET]] on collaborative work and scientific research, and was notable for its research on computer mediated communications, also known as [[groupware]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Electronic enterprises : looking to the future.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p2rIkxJ_eHMC&pg=PA44|publisher=DIANE Publishing|isbn=978-1-4289-2051-4|pages=44–}}</ref>
Starting from the early seventies [[astrophysicist]] and [[computer scientist]] [[Jacques Vallee]], [[sociologist]] Bob Johansen, and technology forecaster [[Paul Saffo]] worked for IFTF.<ref name="Vallee2003">{{cite book|author=Jacques Vallee|title=The Heart of the Internet: An Insider's View of the Origin and Promise of the On-Line Revolution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EH46qowjvasC|year=2003|publisher=Jacques Vallee|isbn=978-1-57174-369-5}}</ref>
=== An increase in corporate focus === In 1975 the Corporate Associates Program was started to assist private organisations interpret emerging trends and the long-term consequences.<ref name="ref_cornish2">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UMbylT5nsD0C&pg=PA241&f=false |title=The Study of the Future: An Introduction to the Art and Science of Understanding and Shaping Tomorrow's World |author=Edward Cornish |page=241 |publisher=Transaction publishers |date=1 January 1977 |quote= |access-date=29 February 2016}}</ref> Although this program operated until 2001, its role as the Institute's main reporting tool was superseded by the Ten Year Forecast in 1978.<ref name="ref_tyf1978">{{cite web |url=http://www.iucat.iu.edu/iub/6623677 |title=''Catalog entry for Ten year forecast'' |publisher=IUCat |quote=''Publishing history: began in 1978'' |access-date=29 February 2016}}</ref>
In 1984 the [[sociologist]] Herbert L Smith noted that, by the late 1970s, the idea of an open Union reporting format had given way to the proprietary Ten Year Forecast. Smith interpreted this as a renewed focus on business forecasting as public funds became scarce.<ref name="ref_smith">{{cite journal |title=''The Social Forecasting Industry'' |journal=Forecasting in the Social and Natural Sciences |editors= Kenneth C. Land, Stephen H. Schneider |author=Herbert L Smith |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=izLrCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA43&f=false#v=onepage&q&f=false |date=1987 |publisher=D. Riedel Publishing Company |isbn= |page=43 |quote= |access-date=24 February 2016}}</ref>
It is not clear how pertinent Smith's observations were to how the Institute was operating in this period. Sociologists such as Bob Johansen continued to be active in the Institute's projects. Having taken part in early ARPANET development, Institute staff were well aware of the impact that computer networking would have on society and its inclusion in policy making.<ref name="ref_NYT">{{cite journal |title=''Study Says Technology Could Transform Society'' |author=Robert Rheinhold |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/14/us/study-says-technology-could-transform-society.html |date=14 June 1982 |publisher=New York Times |isbn= |quote= |access-date=24 February 2016}}</ref> However, in a 1984 essay, Roy Amara appeared to acknowledge some form of crisis, and a renewed interest in societal forecasting.<ref name="ref_Amara">{{cite journal |title=''New directions for futures research —setting the stage'' |author=Roy Amara |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0016328784901034 |date=August 1984 |journal=Futures |publisher=Institute for the Future |isbn= |quote=''Futures research is currently in a state of abeyance and may well be approaching a critical crossroad... The primary focus of futures research in the next decade should be in the public sector where the need is greater,...'' |access-date=25 February 2016|doi=10.1016/0016-3287(84)90103-4 |volume=16 |pages=401–404}}</ref>
=== Evolution of societal forecasting === New ways of presenting studies to a less specialised audience were adopted, or developed. As an aid to memory retention, 'Vignetting' presented future scenarios as short stories; to illustrate the point of the scenario, and engage the reader’s attention.<ref name="ref_vignette">{{cite book |title=Facilitating Learning Organizations: Making Learning Count |author1=Victoria J. Marsick |author2=Karen E. Watkins |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_xu-f2AMbxgC&pg=PA90&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&&f=false |year=1999 |publisher=Gower publishing |pp=90 |isbn= |quote= |access-date=24 February 2016}}</ref> Later initiatives showed an increasing emphasis on narrative engagement, e.g. ‘Artifacts of the future’,<ref name="ref_artifact">{{cite book |title=''A Generous Community: Being the Church in a New Missionary Age'' |author=C. Andrew Doyle |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dID5CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT26&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&f=false |date= 1 October 2015 |publisher=Church publishing inc. |pp=26 |isbn= |quote=''In 2008 Johansen...challenged the group to see bits and pieces of artifacts from the surrounding culture as "provocative moments"'' |access-date=24 February 2016}}</ref> and 'Human-future interaction'.<ref name="ref_hfinteraction">{{cite web |title=Jason Tester: Case for Human-Future Interaction |author=David Pescovitz |url=http://boingboing.net/2007/02/21/jason-tester-case-fo.html |date= 21 February 2007 |publisher=Boing Boing |isbn= |quote= |access-date=25 February 2016}}</ref><ref name="ref_foresight">{{cite book |title=Foresight in Organizations: Methods and Tools |author=Patrick van der Duin |url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=GKZeCwAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PA228#v=onepage&f=false |date=13 January 2016 |publisher=Routledge |page=228 |isbn= |quote= |access-date=25 February 2016}}</ref>
[[Ethnography|Ethnographic]] forecasting was adopted as it became recognised that "society" was actually a myriad of sub-cultures, each with its own outlook. <ref name="ref_AnticAnth">{{cite journal |title=Essays in Anticipatory Anthropology |journal=Futures |author=Victoria M. Razak |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=puB3iqOeAggC |volume=32 |year= 2000 | doi = 10.1016/s0016-3287(00)00022-7 |publisher=Institute for the Future |editor=T Stevenson |pages=717–723 |isbn= |quote= |access-date=25 February 2016}}</ref> <ref name="ref_ethnography">{{cite journal |title=Trusting Strangers: Work Relationships in Four High-Tech Communities |journal=Information, Communication & Society |authors=J.A. English-Lueck, Charles N. Darrah & Andrea Saveri |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13691180110117677 |volume=5 |issue=1 |year= 2002 |publisher=Routledge |editors=Brian D. Loader, William H. Dutton |pages=90–108 |isbn= |quote= |access-date=26 February 2016 |doi=10.1080/13691180110117677}}</ref>
While older forecasting methods sought the advice of field experts, newer techniques sought the statistical input from all members of society. Public interaction, provided via the internet and social media, made it possible to engage in "bottom up forecasting".<ref name="ref_beingandwellbeing">{{cite book |title=Being and Well-Being: Health and the Working Bodies of Silicon Valley |author=J.A. English-Lueck |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q2aMv-cr1bYC&pg=PR10&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&f=false |date= 20 September 2010 |publisher=Stanford University Press |page=x |isbn= |quote= |access-date=25 February 2016}}</ref> While roleplaying and simulation games had long been part of a forecaster's tools, they could now be scaled up into "massively multiplayer forecasting games" such as Superstruct. This game enlisted the blogs and wikis of over 5,000 people to discuss life 10 years in the future; presenting them with a set of hypothetical, overlapping social threats, and encouraging them to seek collaborative "superstruct" solutions.<ref name="ref_mmorpg">{{cite journal |title=''MMOs to help futurists solve world problems?'' |author=Daniel Terdiman |url=http://www.cnet.com/news/mmos-to-help-futurists-solve-world-problems/ |date=9 January 2009 |publisher=CNet |isbn= |quote= |access-date=25 February 2016}}</ref> The concept of the superstruct was subsequently incorporated into the Institute's ‘Foresight Engine’ tool.<ref name="ref_foresightengine">{{cite journal |title=''Foresight 2.0 - Definition, overview & evaluation'' |authors=Jörg Schatzmann, René Schäfer, Frederik Eichelbaum |journal=European Journal of Futures Research |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40309-013-0015-4 |date=December 2013 |publisher= |isbn= |quote= |access-date=25 February 2016 |doi=10.1007/s40309-013-0015-4 |volume=1}}</ref>
== Work == The Institute maintains research programs on the futures of technology, health, and organizations. It publishes a variety of reports and maps, as well as ''Future Now'', a blog on emerging technologies. It offers three programs to its clients: * The Ten year forecast is the Institute's signature piece, having operated since 1978.<ref name="ref_tyf1978"/> It tracks today’s latent signals, and forecasts what they might mean for business in ten years' time.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_BsQudpHXn4C&pg=PA52&hl=en#v=onepage&f=false |title=''Designing Culture: The Technological Imagination at Work'' |pages=52–53 |author=Anne Balsamo |publisher=Duke University Press |date=19 June 2011 |access-date=29 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Schwartz |first1=Ariel |title=Predictions About The Last Decade, From Futurists In 2005|url=http://www.fastcoexist.com/3041052/futurist-forum/predictions-about-the-last-decade-from-futurists-in-2005|accessdate=17 September 2015|publisher=Fast Company|date=20 January 2015}}</ref> * The Technology Horizons program, beginning around 2004,<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.iftf.org/uploads/media/SR-851A_New_Literacy_Cooperation.pdf |title=''Toward a New Literacy of Cooperation in Business'' |authors=Andrea Saveri, Howard Rheingold, Alex Soojung-Kim Pang, and Kathi Vian |date=June 2004 |journal=Technological Horizons Program |publisher=Institute for the Future |quote= |access-date=1 March 2016}}</ref> is described by the Institute as "''combining a deep understanding of technology and societal forces to identify and evaluate discontinuities and innovations in the next three to ten years''".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iftf.org/iftf-you/programs-initiatives/technology-horizons/ |title=IFTF: Technology Horizons |newspaper=IFTF Web site |date= |author= |accessdate= 3 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.mnn.com/green-tech/research-innovations/stories/whats-next-predictions-from-the-institute-for-the-future |title=''What's next? Predictions from the Institute for the Future'' |author=(reprinted from InnovationNewsDaily) |date=11 January 2012 |journal=[[Mother Nature Network]] |publisher= |quote=''Earlier this month, IFTF announced a list of predictions for the next three-to-10 years, at the Technology Horizons Program.'' |access-date=1 March 2016}}</ref> * The Health horizons program has operated since 2005.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.iftf.org/member/system/files/deliverables/SR-900_Top_Ten_Impediments.pdf |title=''Top Ten Impediments to Better Health & Health Care in the United States [SR-900]'' |author=Bern Shen |date=May 2005 |journal=Health Horizons Program |publisher=Institute for the Future |quote= |access-date=1 March 2016}}</ref> The Institute describes its purpose as "''seeking more resilient responses for the complex challenges facing global health''".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iftf.org/healthfutures/ |title=IFTF: Health Horizons |newspaper=IFTF Web site |date= |author= |accessdate= 4 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ie5loN3ycecC&pg=PA42&hl=en&f=false#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=''Get There Early: Sensing the Future to Compete in the Present'' |author=Bob Johansen |date=1 August 2007 |page=42 |publisher=Berrett-Koehler Publishers Inc. |quote= |access-date=1 March 2016}}</ref><!-- re: Primary Sources. While these programs are cited quite widely, it is for their content, not their purpose. This makes it difficult to describe them without recourse to Primary Sources. -->
In 2014 the Institute moved its Headquarters to 201 Hamilton Avenue, [[Palo Alto, California]].<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.paloaltoonline.com/news/2014/06/23/shoptalk-mings-still-open-downtown-retail-moves-out |title=''ShopTalk: Ming's still open, downtown Palo Alto retail moves out'' |author=Daryl Savage |date=23 June 2014 |journal=Palo Alto Online |publisher=Embarcadero Media |quote=''The prestigious think tank Institute for the Future recently moved into 201 Hamilton Ave., at the corner of Emerson Street.'' |access-date=2 March 2016}}</ref>
The Institute's annual publication ''Future Now'' is intended to provide summaries of the Institute's body of research. The inaugural edition was published in February 2017. Its theme ''The New Body Language'' concentrated on the Technology Horizons Program's studies on human and machine symbiosis.
== People == {{As of|2016}} the Institute's executive director is Marina Gorbis. Also associated with the institute are [[David Pescovitz]], [[Anthony M. Townsend]], [[Jane McGonigal]], and [[Jamais Cascio]].
=== Past leaders === * Frank Davidson (1968–70) * Olaf Helmer (1970) * [[Roy Amara]] (1971–90) * Ian Morrison (1990–96) * Bob Johansen (1996-2004) * Peter Banks (2004–06) * Marina Gorbis (2006-) <!-- NB: Some of these names have page refs, but for different people. -->
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{Official website}}
{{Authority control}}
[[Category:1968 establishments in California]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Palo Alto, California]] [[Category:Think tanks based in the United States]] [[Category:Futurology]]

revision.comment: inaccurate information from a biased source, Gloria Allred
revision.text:
The '''Los Angeles fetus disposal scandal''' was the 1982 discovery of over 16,000 aborted fetuses being improperly stored at Malvin Weisberg's [[Woodland Hills, California|Woodland Hills]], California, home and the ensuing legal battle regarding their disposal. It was called a "national tragedy" by the then-president [[Ronald Reagan]] and inspired a song by pop singer [[Pat Boone]], with the fetuses finally buried in 1985. No criminal charges were filed against any of the parties involved.<ref name="sac-bee">{{cite news|last=Raimundo|first=Jeff|title=High court stymies LA burial of fetuses|date=March 19, 1985}}</ref> Weisberg had stored the specimens properly but had not disposed of them due to financial difficulties.<ref name="sac-bee"/>
==Discovery== Malvin Weisberg had operated Medical Analytic Laboratories in [[Santa Monica]] from 1976 until March 1981.<ref name="secret">{{cite news|title=Secret Meeting Set in Fetus Discovery Case|last=Blake|first=Gene|date=11 February 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=SD_A13|}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Meeting on Fetuses|date=18 February 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=D4|}}</ref> He purchased a 20-foot (6.1 m) [[Intermodal container|storage container]] in 1980, delivering it to his Woodland Hills home and paying for it with a [[Non-sufficient funds|bounced check]] for $1700.<ref name="secret" /><ref name="fivehundred" /> The container was repossessed on February 3, 1982, by the [[Martin Container Company]], based in the [[Wilmington, Los Angeles|Wilmington]] area of Los Angeles.<ref name="fivehundred" /> The company opened the container on the following day, discovering the fetuses, which were stored in [[formaldehyde]].<ref name="fivehundred" />
The initial press conference, on February 5, 1982, by the [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services|Los Angeles County Health Department]] said up to 500 fetuses were found.<ref name="fivehundred">{{cite news|title=500 Fetuses Found in Storage|last=Michaelson|first=Judith|date=6 February 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=B6|accessdate=}}</ref> On February 24, 1982, the count of fetuses was raised to approximately 2000, with the majority of them being from the storage container and 200–300 from Weisberg's garage.<ref>{{cite news|title=Officials Find 200 to 400 More Fetuses|date=24 February 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=A3|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Legality of State Abortion Law Doubted: Discovery of 2,000 Fetuses Raises Issue of Validity of Prohibitions|last=Jacobs|first=Paul|date=26 February 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=B1|}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TrlMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OPsDAAAAIBAJ&dq=medical-analytic-laboratories&pg=6593%2C2870422|title=2,000 fetuses linked to out-of-business laboratory|date=25 February 1982|work=[[Lakeland Ledger]]|publisher=[[Associated Press]]|page=19|}}</ref>
The tally of fetuses was estimated at "up to 17,000" in May 1982,<ref name="each" /> and was later finally set at 16,431.<ref name="charges" /> A count of 193 fetuses were evidently over 20 weeks' [[gestation]], with the oldest almost 30 weeks.<ref name="charges" />
State law required the fetuses to be cremated or buried "within a reasonable time".<ref name="depol" />
==Source and age of the fetuses== The fetuses resulted from pregnancies terminated by licensed physicians, clinics and hospitals who contracted Medical Analytic Laboratories for pathology testing and disposal of the fetuses.<ref name="charges" /><ref name="court" />
The [[Los Angeles County District Attorney]], [[John Van de Kamp]],<!-- note Wikipedia states Van de Kamp would have only been in office until 1981, though several articles state he was in office through at least the beginning of the 1982 discovery --> said the fetuses would be individually examined and charges would be filed against the doctors if fetuses were over the 20-week [[gestation]] limit allowed by California law at the time.<ref name="charges" /><ref name="prosecute" /> Officials found 193 fetuses that appeared to be over the 20-week limit.<ref name="charges" /> Van de Kamp wanted to turn the remaining fetuses over to groups who would perform memorial services on them.<ref name="charges" />
In May 1982, [[California Attorney General]] [[George Deukmejian]] stated the gestation limit of the 1967 California abortion law was considered unenforceable because of conflicts with the 23-week [[Roe v. Wade]] ruling in 1973, but fetuses could be individually examined to determine viability, which was the legal limit.<ref name="charges" /><ref name="prosecute" /><ref name="deukmejian">{{cite news|title=Abortion Prosecution Possible-Deukmejian: Opinion Clears Way for Van de Kamp to File Charges in Woodland Hills Case|last=Ingram|first=Carl|author2=Jacobs, Paul |date=11 May 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=OC_A1|accessdate=}}</ref> In late May, Van de Kamp stated every fetus would be examined to determine if the fetus was aborted illegally.<ref name="each">{{cite news|title=Each Stored Fetus to Be Examined: L.A. District Attorney to Decide Whether to File Charges|last=Jones|first=Jack|date=27 May 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=OC4|accessdate=}}</ref>
==Legal action== In 1982 president [[Ronald Reagan]] wrote a letter advocating for memorial services "for these children", referring to it as "this national tragedy".<ref name="court">{{cite news|title=Court Clears the Way for Disposal of Fetuses|last=Hager|first=Philip|date=19 March 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=SD3|accessdate=}}</ref>
The matter came in front of the judge because of a lawsuit filed against Van de Kamp by [[Carol Downer]] of the [[Los Angeles Feminist Women's Health Center]] and the [[American Civil Liberties Union]]. John Lynch, the chief deputy county counsel stated it was inappropriate to enjoin Van de Kamp, who was simply a "man in the middle", and that the lawsuit should be filed against pro-choice groups instead.<ref name="release" /> In June 1982, [[Los Angeles County Superior Court]] judge [[Dickran Tevrizian]] issued a [[temporary restraining order]]<!-- another source calls it VdK as being 'enjoined' --> against Van de Kamp to prevent the unconstitutional release of the fetuses to groups for burial, but allowed him to legally dispose of the fetuses, called "vague" by John Lynch, the chief deputy county counsel.<ref name="depol">{{cite news|title=Depoliticizing the Fetuses|date=11 June 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=D6|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="release">{{cite news|title=Release of Fetuses for Rites Prohibited: Judge's Injunction Forbids Van de Kamp to Allow Their Use in Religious Services|last=Oliver|first=Myrna|date=23 June 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=B3|accessdate=}}</ref>
In October 1982, Van de Kamp petitioned the court to allow the burial of all but the 193 late-term fetuses in [[Mass grave|common graves]] at [[Valhalla Memorial Park Cemetery]], which offered free burial.<ref name="charges" /><ref name="permission">{{cite news|title=Permission Sought for Burial of Fetuses|last=Rohrlich|first=Ted|date=1 October 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=OC_A4|accessdate=}}</ref> The fetuses were not buried at Valhalla, which later stated it offered the burial plot because "the right-to-life groups came to us, and we said we wouldn't endorse any political viewpoint, but we thought that interring the bodies was a proper thing to do as a service".<ref>{{cite news|title=Valhalla Cemetery Records History of Famous, Forgotten|last=Bloom|first=Stephen|date=2 September 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=V_A6|accessdate=}}</ref>
In December 1982, [[Los Angeles Superior Court]] judge Eli Chernow ruled the 20-week limit was unconstitutional, also ruling that Van de Kamp could bury the fetuses and [[pro-life]] groups could hold onsite memorial services.<ref>{{cite news|title=Judge Rejects Abortion Bar at 20 Weeks|last=Oliver|first=Myrna|date=22 December 1982|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=A1|accessdate=}}</ref>
By July 1983, the district attorney was [[Robert Philibosian]], who stated he preferred a "dignified burial" and would not file charges.<ref name="charges">{{cite news|title=D.A. Will Not File Charges in Deaths of 16,431 Fetuses|last=Rohrlich|first=Ted|date=20 August 1983|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=1|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="prosecute" /><ref name="prosecute">{{cite news|title=L.A. County Won't Prosecute in Abortions: Court Fight Still Being Waged on How to Dispose of 16,431 Fetuses|last=Rohrlich|first=Ted|date=20 August 1983|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=A6|accessdate=}}</ref>
In July 1984, the [[California Courts of Appeal]] overturned [[Superior Court of Los Angeles County]] judge Eli Chernow, ruling the fetuses could not be buried as human remains, which was a win for [[pro-choice]] groups and feminists. The case had been appealed by [[Carol Downer]] of the [[Los Angeles Feminist Women's Health Center]] and the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] and was denounced by the California Pro-Life Medical Association, the [[Catholic League (U.S.)|Catholic League]]. The appealing parties argued that allowing [[Pro-life movement|pro-life]] groups to bury the remains violated the [[separation of church and state]]. The Court's opinion stated "it is clear from the record that the Catholic League is a religious organization which regards a fetus as a human being and abortion as murder. While this specific belief may well cross sectarian lines... any state action showing a preference for this belief will be strictly scrutinized and must be invalidated". Since fetal remains are normally incinerated without ceremony, there was no reason to do otherwise with these fetuses, stating "We perceive that the intended burial ceremony will enlist the prestige and power of the state. This is constitutionally forbidden." However, religious services could hold concurrent onsite memorial services, which was praised by US president [[Ronald Reagan]] in a letter to the California Pro-Life Medical Association, admiring their decision "to hold a memorial service for these children".<ref name="prosecute" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Appeal Court Bars Disputed Plan to Bury 16,000 Fetuses|last=Blake|first=Gene|date=3 July 1984|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=C1|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="rehnquist" /> Philibosian announced he would appeal the ruling allowing onsite memorial services.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Region|date=10 July 1984|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=SD2|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="issue">{{cite news|title=County Will Take Fetus Issue to U.S. High Court|last=Hernandez|first=Marita|date=28 September 1984|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=D1|accessdate=}}</ref> In October 1984, [[U.S. Supreme Court]] justice [[William Rehnquist]] refused to turn over the state appeals court ruling allowing the religious ceremonies.<ref name="rehnquist">{{cite news|title=The Region: U.S. Supreme Court...|date=12 October 1984|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=OC2|accessdate=}}</ref> This was officially upheld by the Supreme Court in March 1985.<ref>{{cite news|title=L.A. County Loses Plea to Bury 16,500 Fetuses (UPI)|date=18 March 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=A2|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Court Clears the Way for Disposal of Fetuses|last=Hager|first=Philip|date=19 March 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=}}</ref>
==Pro-life service== In May 1985, singer [[Pat Boone]] announced he recorded a song titled "Sixteen Thousand Faces" about the incident, first played at a pro-life memorial service for the fetuses at [[Live Oak Memorial Park]] in [[Monrovia, California|Monrovia]], where a granite tombstone was left with the inscription "For all those deprived of life and human love through abortion". In response, the California [[Abortion Rights Action League]] director said the service and marker "[humanized] fetuses when they deny the humanity of women already born".<ref>{{cite news|title=Boone Song Inspired by Fetus Protest|date=14 May 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=OC17|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Fetuses Left Unburied Prompt Song by Pat Boone|last=Jalon|first=Allan|date=14 May 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=V_A6|accessdate=}}</ref> The ceremony was attended by "several hundred anti-abortionists", including Representative [[Bob Dornan]] and the [[Feminists for Life]] group. At the time, the fetuses had not been disposed of.<ref name="hundred">{{cite news|title=Several Hundred Anti-Abortionists Attend Service for Fetuses|last=Baker|first=Bob|date=20 May 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=C2|accessdate=}}</ref>
==Disposition== In August 1985, the [[Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors]] ordered the fetuses be turned over to the Guerra-Gutirrez-Alexander Mortuary for burial.<ref name="gga" /> Per the court's order, the mortuary was selected because they did not have a religious affiliation.<ref name="challenges" /> At the time, it was noted by the [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]] that the fetuses had been kept in "five pine boxes". The department assured ACLU that there were no identifying marks on canisters containing the fetuses, and ACLU stated they would not object to a secular burial.<ref name="gga">{{cite news|title=County Orders Burial of Controversial Fetuses|last=McGarry|first=T.W.|date=28 August 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=V_A6|accessdate=}}</ref> While ACLU would not object, the Feminist Women's Health Center petitioned the Los Angeles Superior Court to block the burial, but the courts refused.<ref name="challenges">{{cite news|title=Feminist Center Challenges Planned Burial of Fetuses|last=Townsend|first=Dorothy|date=14 September 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=V_A8|accessdate=}}</ref>
The disposition occurred on October 6, 1985, with the fetuses in six pine boxes, which were buried at the [[Odd Fellows Cemetery (Los Angeles, California)|Odd Fellows Cemetery]] in [[Boyle Heights]]. The pro-life group Feminists for Life didn't plan a full memorial service since they held a service in May, but the Americans Committed to Loving the Unwanted held a service. The Feminist Women's Health Center was dismayed over the public burial.<ref>{{cite news|title=Controversial Fetuses to Be Buried Oct. 6: 3-Year Battle Over Interment to End in East L.A. Cemetery|last=Jalon|first=Allan|date=29 September 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=SD25|accessdate=}}</ref> About 250 individuals attended the service, including [[Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors|County Supervisor]] [[Michael D. Antonovich]], who read a message from Ronald Reagan but stressed his attendance was in an unofficial capacity. Reagan's message stated "Just as the terrible toll of Gettysburg can be traced to a tragic decision of a divided Supreme Court, so also can these deaths we mourn. Once again a whole category of human beings has been ruled outside the protection of the law by a court ruling which clashed with our deepest moral convictions." Others in attendance were Representative [[Bob Dornan]], state Senate President [[David A. Roberti]], and state Representative [[Joseph Montoya (California)|Joseph Montoya]]. The pro-life group Americans Committed to Loving the Unwanted organized the service, including requesting a three-man Marine Corps [[color guard]], who placed an [[American flag]] on a box and stood at attention throughout the service.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fetuses Buried-With Hymns, Prayers|last=McGarry|first=TW|date=7 October 1985|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=A3|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1985-10-07/news/0330340020_1_aborted-fetuses-supreme-court-tabernacle-of-faith|title=Aborted Fetuses Get Religious Burial Reagan Sends Message To Ceremony In Los Angeles|last=|first=|date=7 October 1985|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>
==Financial fallout== Weisberg's Medical Analytical Laboratories received nearly $175,000 in [[Medi-Cal]] payments, with $88,000 coming from pathology tests on aborted fetuses. Of this, half of it ($44,000) was paid federally through the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]] (HHS). By the [[Hyde Amendment]], this money was ineligible for testing on pre-abortion or post-abortion tissue, which meant the state of California would need to pay back federal funds claimed by Weisberg and by any other laboratories, according to HHS inspector Richard P. Kusserow. Kusserow also stated "prior to its closing in April, 1981, [Medical Analytical Laboratories] had routinely submitted questionable billings under the Medi-Cal program, using an erroneous billing code.... the case lacked criminal prosecutive merit due to a lack of proof that the false billings were intentional. Because the laboratory was out of business, and its owner had declared bankruptcy, there were no assets against which to proceed for civil recovery".<ref name="hhs">{{cite news|title=State May Owe U.S. Millions for Tests on Fetuses|last=Jackson|first=Robert|date=29 May 1983|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=A12|accessdate=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Morning Glory Funeral Home scandal]] * [[Tri-State Crematory]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Abortion in the United States]] [[Category:History of Los Angeles]] [[Category:Legal aspects of death]] [[Category:Scandals in the United States]] [[Category:Undertaking]] [[Category:1982 in California]] [[Category:Funeral scandals]]

revision.comment: Alter: page, isbn. Formatted [[WP:ENDASH|dashes]]. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{Ancient Roman religion}} In [[Religion in ancient Rome|ancient Roman religion]], the '''''Manes''''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|eɪ|n|iː|z}} or '''''Di Manes''''' are [[chthonic]] deities sometimes thought to represent souls of deceased loved ones. They were associated with the ''[[Lares]]'', ''[[Lemures]],'' ''[[Genius (mythology)|Genii]]'', and ''[[Di Penates]]'' as deities (''[[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#deus, dea, di, dii|di]]'') that pertained to domestic, local, and personal cult. They belonged broadly to the category of ''[[di inferi]]'', "those who dwell below,"{{Citation |author=Varro |authorlink=Marcus Terentius Varro |date=1938 |title=De Lingua Latina |url=https://archive.org/details/onlatinlanguage01varruoft |location=London |publisher=W. Heinemann |chapter=6.13 |page=185–7 }}, translated by Kent, Roland G. the undifferentiated collective of divine dead.{{Citation |title=Death |date=2010 |editor-last=Gagarin |editor-first=Michael |encyclopedia=The Oxford Encyclopedia of Ancient Greece and Rome |volume=2 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=9780195170726 |page=366 }}. The Manes were honored during the [[Parentalia]] and [[Feralia]] in February. The theologian [[Augustine of Hippo|St. Augustine]], writing about the subject a few centuries after most of the Latin pagan references to such spirits, differentiated Manes from other types of Roman spirits: {{quotation| [[Apuleius]] "says, indeed, that the souls of men are demons, and that men become ''[[Lares]]'' if they are good, ''[[Lemures]]'' or ''[[Larvae (Roman religion)|Larvae]]'' if they are bad, and ''Manes'' if it is uncertain whether they deserve well or ill... He also states that the blessed are called in Greek εὐδαίμονες [''eudaimones''], because they are good souls, that is to say, good demons, confirming his opinion that the souls of men are demons." |City of God, Book IX, Chapter 11{{Citation |author=St. Augustine of Hippo |authorlink=Augustine of Hippo |year=1871 |title=City of God |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/45304 |location=Edinburgh |publisher=T. & T. Clark |volume=1 |page=365 |accessdate=2016-09-15 }}, translated by the Rev. Marcus Dods, M.A.}} Latin spells of antiquity were often addressed to the Manes.{{Citation |last=Gager |first=John G. |title=Curse Tablets and Binding Spells from the Ancient World |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rmhw2eVJnS0C&pg=PA12 |date=1992 |publisher=Oxford University Press US |isbn=978-0-19-513482-7 |pages=12–13 |accessdate=2010-08-22 }}. ==Etymology and inscriptions== [[File:Stele Licinia Amias Terme 67646.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The abbreviation ''D.M.'' at the top of this 3rd-century Christian tombstone stands for ''Diis Manibus'', "to the Spirits of the Dead"]] Manes may be derived from "an archaic adjective manus —''good''— which was the opposite of immanis (monstrous)".{{Citation |last1=Aldington |first1=Richard |authorlink1=Richard Aldington |last2=Ames |first2=Delano |authorlink2=Delano Ames |year=1968 |title=New Larousse Encyclopedia of Mythology |location=Yugoslavia |publisher=[[Hamlyn (publishers)|Hamlyn Publishing Group Ltd]] |page=213 }}. Roman tombstones often included the letters ''D.M.'', which stood for ''diis manibus'', "for the ghost-gods" or figuratively translated, "for the Manes", an abbreviation that continued to appear even in Christian inscriptions. The Manes were offered blood sacrifices. The [[gladiator|gladiatorial games]], originally held at funerals, may have been instituted in the honor of the Manes. According to [[Cicero]], the ''Manes'' could be called forth from the caves near [[Lake Avernus]]. ==Lapis manalis== {{Main|Lapis manalis}} When a new town was founded, a round hole would be dug and a stone called a ''lapis manalis'' would be placed in the foundations, representing a gate to the [[Hades|underworld]]. Due to similar names, the ''lapis manalis'' is often confused with the ''lapis manilis'' in commentaries even in antiquity: "The 'flowing stone' … must not be confused with the stone of the same name which, according to [[Festus (historian)|Festus]], was the gateway to the underworld."{{Citation |last=Burriss |first=Eli Edward |date=1931 |title=Taboo, Magic, Spirits: A Study of Primitive Elements in Roman Religion |location=New York City |publisher=Macmillan Company |url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/tms/tms06.htm#fr_365 |page=365 |accessdate=2007-08-21 }}. Cyril Bailey writes:
"Of this we have a characteristic example in the ceremony of the ''[[aquaelicium]]'', designed to produce rain after a long drought. In classical times the ceremony consisted in a procession headed by the [[College of Pontiffs|pontifices]], which bore the sacred [[rain-stone]] from its resting-place by the [[Porta Capena]] to the [[Capitolium|Capitol]], where offerings were made to the sky-deity, Iuppiter, but from the analogy of other primitive cults and the sacred title of the stone (''[[lapis manalis]]''), it is practically certain that the original ritual was the purely imitative process of pouring water over the stone.{{Citation |last=Bailey |first=Cyril |date=1907 |title=The Religion of Ancient Rome |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/18564 |location=London |publisher=Archibald Constable & Co. Ltd. |page=5 |accessdate=2007-08-21 }}.
==Notes== {{reflist | 2}} [[Category:Undead]] [[Category:Roman underworld]] [[Category:Ghosts]]
